head.title: Iraq Says It Resolves Saudi Jet's Hijacking

hedline.hl1: Iraq Says It Resolves Saudi Jet's Hijacking

block.p: At least two men, apparently armed with explosives, hijacked a Saudi Arabian passenger jet enroute to London today and forced it to land in Baghdad, where after three hours Iraqi officials announced that they had succeeded in negotiating the freedom of all those on board.

The 90 passengers and 15 crew members, including one American traveler and 40 British citizens, were in good health, Iraqi officials said. The hijackers, whose demands were not made public, were reportedly taken into custody.

At least two men, apparently armed with explosives, hijacked a Saudi Arabian passenger jet enroute to London today and forced it to land in Baghdad, where after three hours Iraqi officials announced that they had succeeded in negotiating the freedom of all those on board.

The 90 passengers and 15 crew members, including one American traveler and 40 British citizens, were in good health, Iraqi officials said. The hijackers, whose demands were not made public, were reportedly taken into custody.
Saudi Arabian Airlines Flight 115 originated in the Saudi port city of Jidda.
